subject: Re: [junit] Unit Testing vs Integration Testing

messageBody:
Mike:

Thanks for the question. First, both integration and unit testing are
extremely valuable and have their place. Integration tests do as you
state. They can be used to validate proper system-wide behavior, and
they may well exercise a lot of code in the process. However, when an
integration test fails how do you know where to start looking for the
underlying cause? This is where unit tests come in. If you write unit
tests as you write your software (or write the tests first as in TDD)
you will have a rich set of tests that exercise your code at a low
level. This way you can be assured that each individual class and method
is doing what it was designed to do. Integration tests then test the
interaction of these fully-tested modules. If an integration test fails,
and all the modules that are involved in that test each passed their
unit tests then
a) Perhaps the unit tests were inadequate and all desired behavior was
not tested
b) Perhaps there is a misunderstanding between the modules, each of
which is behaving 'properly'.

Because I have a pretty thorough set of unit tests, if an integration
test fails I immediately suspect that there is a misunderstanding
between what one module is providing and what is expected. When I find
the root cause, it is usually one of two things -- either I did not pay
attention to my own documentation of the interface and assume a wrong
return type (array of Strings vs a Vector of Strings for example), or I
did not properly test all the functionality in a module that I should
have. If I misunderstood the interface, I fix that (update documentation
as appropriate) and go on. If I had not properly tested the
functionality, I add unit tests, fix the problem and continue.

I find that my experience is exactly counter to your 'naive hunch' in
that my cost per bug eliminated is much less if I have unit tests.
Further, I find myself asking a key question whenever I am adding
functionality: "How will I test this automatically?" I find that when I
ask this question first and make testability a key requirement in adding
functionality two things happen. First, I write better code, more
modular, more loosely coupled, and smaller -- less code does more work.
Second, I have a lot fewer bugs uncovered during any level of testing.
This yields an even better unintended side effect -- more working code
in less time.

One last thing. Unfortunately I can't provide scientific numbers, only
my own experience. Yours may vary. I have found myself being drawn into
the mode of writing tests first (and writing javadoc at the same time)
because it works for me. I was always a firm believer in testing, and
that someone else should do it. Now I am in a small company with no QA
department and I have to write the software as well as ensure it works
and support the end users. To do this I write javadoc and religiously
maintain it. I write unit tests religiously. And I write integration
tests. I do all of this in less time than I used to just write code.
Again, your mileage may vary, but this approach definitely works for me.

Hopefully others will chime much more eloquently than I on this.

Frank



On Fri, 2003-06-20 at 10:54, Mike Bresnahan wrote:

> I have experience with integration testing but not much with unit testing.
> I've been reading up on unit testing (e.g. mock objects, test first
> development). However, I have not found an article that explains the
> advantages of unit testing vs integration testing. My perhaps naive hunch
> is that the cost-per-bug-eliminated of unit testing is higher than that of
> integration testing. It appears this way because a single integration test
> tests a lot more code than a single unit test and takes about the same
> amount of time to construct. Plus it seems to me that a whole suite of unit
> tests with 100% code coverage cannot guarantee that even the simplest system
> wide behavior is correct (e.g. the web page appears). Am I wrong about
> this? Can someone refer me information about this topic. A scientific
> study paper with real numbers would be welcome.
>
> Mike Bresnahan
